bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, June 1, 1923

div1.p: Hanson approves of Carter's paper concerning yellow fever in Australia and Asia. Hanson offers his opinion on the world-wide campaign against yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, June 1, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Australia
HENRY HANSON, M. D.
L A B O R A T O R Y
460 ST. JAMES BLDG.
JACKSONVILLE, FLORIDA
June 1, 1923
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have read and reread your paper
on “The Chance of the Extension of Yellow Fever
to
Asia and Australasia”.

It is good, excellent, and if those who are re-
sponsible for the yellow fever work read it and think
carefully they should certainly be impelled to increase
the efforts for its elimination. It puts the situation
in its true aspect.

I have felt that there was not enough genuine
effort put into the project of the world wide campign
against yellow fever. There has been too much delay in
putting the program into execution, why I do not know,
unless it be that some who have this in charge do not
fully understand the disease, its epidemiology etc.

I have felt fully convinced that its elimination
were possible, but it will not be if there is much more
delay in the utilization of the available means to do so.

I am returning this paper now, and want to thank
you for the opportunity of reading it.

I have had no news from Karl since Mrs. Hanson's
arrival and presume that to be a good omen.

As you say in your letter, the yellow fever evi-
dence seems to be against America as the original focus.
The fact that we have only the one species of Aegyti would
indicate that this too had been imported, otherwise it ought
to have some sub+species.
